Investigate whether we can fix this for M7.

No steps. When I tried it again it worked.

Note: I change linked annotations to be all of type Box.
looks like bug 50780, which has steps to reproduce (even outside segmented view).
*** Bug 51656 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 50780 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

StyledText is not meant to handle text changes that are made in a text change 
callback.  From EC article http://eclipse.org/articles/StyledText%
202/article2.html :

The StyledText widget also does not handle nested text content updates, so when 
processing text content changes, the application should not use API that will 
cause text updates to occur.

Perhaps your content changes can be performed asynchronously?

Then, we have to adapt IDocumentExtension.addPostNotificationReplace
  - either, change the contrat so it should only be used when it is known that
the document change triggering the post notification replace originated in a
non-StyledText edition (1)
  - or modify the post notification replace implementation to discriminate
between  changing the document through styled text or through direct document
access (2)

I favor (2), but this will not be an easy one as there may be timing assumptions
all over the code and the solution would be some asynchronous posting of some
kind. (1) is very hard to impossible to do in the general case.

Regarding comment 7: Fair enough - but I suggest to add such limitations to the
API Javadoc since you cannot assume external documents to be part of the API
contract.

At the moment the linked position environment detects relevant changes by
listening to the model and triggering changes to linked positions thereafter.
This way it can react the same way to changes through StyledText and other
document editions (e.g. by content assist). Linked changes are attached to the
original model change using registerPostNotificationReplace.

To avoid the problem outlined in this PR, we have to:
- listen both for model changes (IDocumentListener) and for changes that come in
through StyledText (be a VerifyListener)
- in the latter case, we have to veto the VerifyEvent and perform the document
change ourselves.

fixed > 20040315

LinkedUIControl ensures now that any incoming changes are performed on the model
and any change coming in from StyledText is vetoed and then emulated.
